testimony.name: Max Davidson
key_points: Support for City of Yes initiative to address housing shortage
New York's legacy as a haven for immigrants is at risk due to housing crisis
Housing shortage gives too much power to landlords over tenants
City of Yes provides a first step towards rebalancing power towards tenants
Support for increasing density and height for transit-oriented development, especially in affluent white neighborhoods
Recommendation to expand UAP and identify opportunities to deepen levels of affordability
Suggestion to explore ways to add market-rate units in exchange for deeper affordability
Proposal to average affordability levels between developments in different neighborhoods
Encouragement to strengthen the City of Yes initiative to meet the needs of all New Yorkers

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Additionally, I want to recommend DCP or to expand UAP and identify creative opportunities to deepen levels of affordability.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote directly mentions UAP (Universal Affordability Preference) and discusses expanding it, which is a clear reference to this element of the City of Yes For Housing Opportunity proposal.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: From any working class New Yorkers, 60 percent AMI is too high. To offer 2 recommendations, perhaps DCP can explore ways to make to add additional as of right market rate units on the condition that that allows for deeper affordability at 50% or 40% AMI.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote discusses the affordability levels of the UAP, mentioning the 60% AMI threshold and suggesting modifications to allow for deeper affordability, which is directly related to the UAP element of the proposal.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Alternatively, if a developer is building in, say, the West Village And Crown Heights, perhaps they can average between 2 different developments. So reaching 70 percent AMI in the village, whether it's a high willingness to pay, but achieving 50% afford AMI in Crown Heights, which is a much more working class neighborhood.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote proposes modifications to the UAP element, suggesting a way to adjust affordability levels based on neighborhood characteristics, which is directly related to the Universal Affordability Preference part of the proposal.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: I support his proposal to increase density and height for transit oriented development, particularly in affluent white neighborhoods that were down zoned under the Bloomberg administration ratio.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote directly mentions transit-oriented development and discusses increasing density and height near transit, which is a key aspect of the Transit-Oriented Development element of the City of Yes For Housing Opportunity proposal.
